scenario_0.summary: During a high-priority restocking and inspection cycle, two workers process newly received inventory for immediate storage. Worker 1 transports goods from the receiving point (Area 2) into the inspection area (Area 3), then, after staging and partial inspection, repeatedly moves items down the main corridor from Area 3 toward Shelf 6 for storage. Worker 2 works in parallel at the inspection area, rapidly checking items before also transporting them to Shelf 6 for replenishment, often alternating or collaborating with Worker 1 along the same corridor. Both workers’ primary workflow repeatedly and densely overlaps the robot’s fixed route (G12 to E21), leading to minimal average distance between robot and workers due to their shared transport, staging, and storage activities across the same zones and waypoints, all driven by the urgent need for efficient staging, inspection, and storage replenishment in the core central corridor.

scenario_1.summary: In a high-throughput outbound project, two warehouse workers simultaneously perform mobile quality control, sorting, and relabeling directly within the main corridor between Shelf 6 and Area 3, which completely overlaps the robot’s fixed transport route (G12 to E21). Worker 1 removes and inspects goods from Shelf 6, performs sorting and repacking side-by-side with Worker 2—who fetches supplies and alternates helping with labeling and staging—all within and along the corridor's primary waypoints. Both workers repeatedly traverse and occupy waypoints on and near the robot’s path as they shuttle items between Shelf 6, Area 3, and Area 5, alternating retrieval, inspection, and delivery tasks. The need for rapid, batch processing of urgent outbound goods creates dense, persistent human presence across the robot’s route, naturally minimizing the average distance between the robot and either worker by ensuring frequent, dynamic overlap and adjacency at multiple points during the robot’s operation.

scenario_2.summary: During a high-volume returns triage cycle, two workers operate in parallel: each starts at Area 5 to collect return parcels, transports them to Area 3 for shared inspection, then sorts each item for either restocking at Shelf 6 or disposal in the Waste Area. Both repeatedly move through the main corridors spanning G12–E21 (the robot's fixed route), either side-by-side or asynchronously, as they deliver restockables to Shelf 6 or waste to the Waste Area. Their independent but frequently overlapping workflows generate persistent and dense human presence along the robot’s path, minimizing the average distance between the robot and at least one worker at all times, as frequent staging, delivery, and return trips force them to share space with the robot across the central warehouse axes. All proximity arises naturally from high-traffic, task-driven returns management, with no direct human-robot communication or contrived movement.

scenario_3.summary: During a synchronized quarterly audit and urgent stock transfer process, two workers operate side-by-side using a shared mobile workstation positioned near Area 3 and Shelf 6. Worker 1 audits segments of Shelf 6 and simultaneously stages transfer-requested stock from those sections at Area 3, while Worker 2 cross-verifies the audit, fetches replenishment items from Area 1/2, and restocks Shelf 6 immediately after each audited transfer. Both routinely converge at the shared workstation and Shelf 6, repeatedly traversing the main corridor (G12 to E21) alongside and sometimes together with the robot as it executes its fixed route. Frequent, collaborative use of the shared mobile workstation and space-constrained, segment-by-segment workflow ensure both workers remain in tightly overlapping proximity to the robot’s path throughout the process, minimizing the average distance between the robot and humans on the route due to real-world, audit-driven task demands and not intentional co-location.

scenario_4.summary: During a peak JIT dispatch operation triggered by a surge in outbound orders, Worker 1 continuously shuttles between Area 1 (collecting batch components), Area 3 (consolidating items), and Area 5 (picking up packing materials), then moves packed bins via the F-row and E-row corridors to the E18–E21 segment at Shelf 6. Worker 2, tasked with labeling, quality checking, and finalizing orders, alternates between Area 3 (receiving new bins), the E18–E21 corridor/border (preparing and staging ready orders at Shelf 6), and backtracking toward Area 3 for missing packing slips or urgent order confirmation. Both workers frequently occupy, cross paths on, or dwell along the robot’s G12–E21 path due to overlapping, urgency-driven handoffs and batch staging, especially at corridor bottlenecks or mutual retrievals, ensuring minimal physical distance to the robot throughout the process. All proximity arises organically from legitimate, high-intensity outbound order consolidation needs and dynamic environmental adaptation rather than engineered human-robot co-location.

scenario_5.summary: During an urgent post-sales replenishment operation, Worker 1 repeatedly shuttles new product bins from Area 2 to Area 3, where bins are rapidly split and staged for immediate labeling. Worker 2 simultaneously performs live bin labeling, following Worker 1’s splits and conducting handoffs in Area 3, then both workers transport labeled bins side-by-side or in overlapping waves along the main corridor (waypoints G12–E21) to place items onto Shelf 6. The intensity and pace of distributed, shared bin handling—requiring continuous, back-and-forth movement, alternating or shared bin transport, and frequent handoffs within narrow corridor space—cause both workers to occupy the robot’s fixed path (G12–E21) for the majority of each cycle. Because high task density and synchronized activity naturally maximize overlap at all main corridor grid points, the robot’s average distance to the nearest worker is minimized throughout, arising solely from operational needs for efficient, high-volume bin processing and labeling in a constrained environment.

scenario_6.summary: During a large-scale cross-docking and outbound order-building operation, two workers collaborate to assemble mixed-SKU pallet shipments using goods from bulk overflow storage (Large Shelf 4), recent inbound arrivals (Area 3), and fast-access stock (Shelf 6). Worker 1 shuttles items between Large Shelf 4, staging them at Area 3, and then moves assembled orders toward Shelf 6 for picking and dispatch. Worker 2 supports by rapidly receiving and checking inbound items at Area 3, retrieving additional SKUs from Shelf 6, and confirming quantities at Large Shelf 4, frequently alternating or working in tandem with Worker 1. Both workers perform batch staging, order reconciliation, and physical handoffs in or adjacent to Area 3 and along the main G12–E21 corridor—the robot's fixed route—resulting in persistent and dense overlap as each assembly cycle requires repeated proximity to the robot's path. Their legitimate, operationally driven movement and task requirements produce naturally minimized robot-to-worker distances, as both workers repeatedly transit, dwell, and interact within the core corridor, especially at high-overlap staging points, with all proximity arising organically from complex cross-dock assembly processes.

scenario_7.summary: In response to an unplanned surge event and simultaneous stock imbalance notification, Worker 1 and Worker 2 engage in overlapping kit-building and dynamic stock-balancing operations centered on Area 3 and Shelf 6. Worker 1 shuttles kit components from Areas 1/2 to Area 3, assembles kits, and repeatedly moves to Shelf 6 for last-minute SKU retrievals and ad-hoc inventory tally transfers, returning to Area 3 via the main corridor. Worker 2 assists in kit assembly, stages finished kits from Area 3 to the end of Shelf 6 for dispatch, and performs urgent restocking by moving supplies from incoming bins (Area 2/5) to Shelf 6. Both workers frequently alternate, overlap, or coincide at Area 3, along corridors F12–F18, and E18–E21, naturally sharing and crossing the robot's fixed route (G12 to E21) with persistent, role-driven proximity as they repeatedly fetch, deliver, assemble, and balance stock in real time. All overlap and reduced average distance arise solely from the operational intensity and bidirectional demands of surge kit assembly and live inventory adjustment, not intentional co-location or communication with the robot.

scenario_8.summary: During an urgent inventory integrity check triggered by a suspected leak, Worker 1 (Inventory Auditor) and Worker 2 (Emergency Redistribution Specialist) conduct a rapid, overlapping triage and salvage operation. Worker 1 scans and inspects affected stock along Shelf 6, repeatedly transferring items to and from Area 3 for damage assessment, while Worker 2 cycles between Area 3, Shelf 6, Area 5, and the Waste Area to remove high-risk or contaminated items. Both workers persistently co-occupy the G12–E21 corridor, moving bins, staging recovered goods, and urgently shuttling between audits, removal, and prepping for redistribution. Their dense, emergency-driven collaboration and constant hands-on activity along the robot’s fixed route ensure the robot is nearly always in physical proximity to at least one worker. No actions are contrived for proximity; all overlap arises naturally from real, incident-driven warehouse salvage and assessment procedures.

scenario_9.summary: After a sudden bulk inventory surge, Workers 1 and 2 conduct simultaneous, multi-zone overflow redistribution and dynamic buffer management: Worker 1 rapidly transfers boxes from Region 1 (Boxes 1/2) through F12/G12 to buffer-drop at Areas 1 and 3, then cycles between Area 3 and Shelf 6 via the full G12–E21 corridor and occasionally Large Shelf 2. Meanwhile, Worker 2 collects overflow from Boxes 3 and Area 1, stages and sorts in Area 3, and repeatedly shuttles between Area 3, Area 5, and Shelf 6, moving shelfable boxes and retrieving buffer loads. Both frequently perform parallel or alternating staging at Area 3 and use the main corridor for nearly all zone transitions, resulting in repeated, organic co-occupation, handoffs, and near-collisions along the fixed robot path (G12–E21). This high-frequency, bidirectional, multi-zone redistribution—dictated by legitimate operational necessity and not contrived human-robot co-location—naturally minimizes the robot’s average distance to the nearest worker throughout its route.
